rule.name: Rule template for Cppcheck custom rules
rule.description:
Follow these steps to make your custom rules available in SonarQube:

    1. Create a new rule in SonarQube by "copying" this rule template and specify the CheckId of your custom rule, a title, a description, and a default severity.
    2. Enable the newly created rule in your quality profile
  1. Relaunch an analysis on your projects, et voila, your custom rules are executed!

rule.name: Unknown Cppcheck rule
rule.description: By activating this rule, unknown rules in the reports are not discarded but mapped to this rule. This helps to identify unknown rules, e.g. from newer versions of a tool.

rule.name: Assigning a pointer to an integer is not portable
rule.description:
Assigning a pointer to an integer (int/long/etc) is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up assigning 64-bit address to 32-bit integer. The safe way is to store addresses only in pointer types (or typedefs like uintptr_t).

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: Assigning an integer to a pointer is not portable
rule.description:
Assigning an integer (int/long/etc) to a pointer is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up assigning 64-bit integer to 32-bit pointer. The safe way is to store addresses only in pointer types (or typedefs like uintptr_t).

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: Returning an address value in a function with integer return type is not portable
rule.description:
Returning an address value in a function with integer (int/long/etc) return type is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and Linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and Linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up casting 64-bit address down to 32-bit integer. The safe way is to always return an integer.

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.name: Returning an integer in a function with pointer return type is not portable
rule.description:
Returning an integer (int/long/etc) in a function with pointer return type is not portable across different platforms and compilers. For example in 32-bit Windows and Linux they are same width, but in 64-bit Windows and Linux they are of different width. In worst case you end up casting 64-bit integer down to 32-bit pointer. The safe way is to always return a pointer.

References

CWE-758: Reliance on Undefined, Unspecified, or Implementation-Defined Behavior

rule.description: Skipping configuration 'X' since the value of 'X' is unknown. Use -D if you want to check it. You can use -U to skip it explicitly.

rule.name: Array index 'i' is used before limits check
rule.description:
Defensive programming: The variable 'i' is used as an array index before it is checked that is within limits. This can mean that the array might be accessed out of bounds. Reorder conditions such as '(a[i] && i < 10)' to '(i < 10 && a[i])'. That way the array will not be accessed if the index is out of limits.

rule.description:

rule.name: Address of local auto-variable assigned to a function parameter

rule.description:
When using 'char' variables in bit operations, sign extension can generate unexpected results. For example: char c = 0x80; int i = 0 | c; if (i & 0x8000) printf("not expected"); The "not expected" will be printed on the screen.

rule.name: Storing func_name() return value in char variable and then comparing with EOF
rule.description:
When saving func_name() return value in char variable there is loss of precision. When func_name() returns EOF this value is truncated. Comparing the char variable with EOF can have unexpected results. For instance a loop "while (EOF != (c = func_name());" loops forever on some compilers/platforms and on other compilers/platforms it will stop when the file contains a matching character.

rule.description:

rule.name: In expression like '*A++' the result of '*' is unused. Did you intend to write '(*A)++;'?
rule.description:
A statement like '*A++;' might not do what you intended. Postfix 'operator++' is executed before 'operator*'. Thus, the dereference is meaningless. Did you intend to write '(*A)++;'?

rule.name: Comma is used in return statement. The comma can easily be misread as a ';'
rule.description:
Comma is used in return statement. When comma is used in a return statement it can easily be misread as a semicolon. For example in the code below the value of 'b' is returned if the condition is true, but it is easy to think that 'a+1' is returned: if (x) return a + 1, b++; However it can be useful to use comma in macros. Cppcheck does not warn when such a macro is then used in a return statement, it is less likely such code is misunderstood.

References

rule.name: C-style pointer casting
rule.description:
C-style pointer casting detected. C++ offers four different kinds of casts as replacements: static_cast, const_cast, dynamic_cast and reinterpret_cast. A C-style cast could evaluate to any of those automatically, thus it is considered safer if the programmer explicitly states which kind of cast is expected. See also: https://ww w.securecoding.cert.org/confluence/display/cplusplus/EXP05-CPP.+Do+not +use+C-style+casts.

rule.name: Technically the member function 'class::function' can be static (but you may consider moving to unnamed namespace)
rule.description:
The member function 'class::function' can be made a static function. Making a function static can bring a performance benefit since no 'this' instance is passed to the function. This change should not cause compiler errors but it does not necessarily make sense conceptually. Think about your design and the task of the function first - is it a function that must not access members of class instances? And maybe it is more appropriate to move this function to a unnamed namespace.

rule.name: scanf() without field width limits can crash with huge input data
rule.description:
scanf() without field width limits can crash with huge input data. Add a field width specifier to fix this problem. Sample program that can crash: #include <stdio.h> int main() { char c[5]; scanf("%s", c); return 0; } Typing in 5 or more characters may make the program crash. The correct usage here is 'scanf("%4s", c);', as the maximum field width does not include the terminating null byte. Source: http://linux.die.net/man/3/scanf Source: http://www.opensource.appl e.com/source/xnu/xnu-1456.1.26/libkern/stdio/scanf.c

References

CWE-119: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

rule.description: scanf without field width limits can crash with huge input data on libc versions older than 2.13-25. Add a field width specifier to fix this problem:\012 %i => %3i\012\012Sample program that can crash:\012\012#include <stdio.h>\012int main()\012{\012 int a;\012 scanf("%i", &a);\012 return 0;\012}\012\012To make it crash:\012perl -e 'print "5"x2100000' | ./a.out

The 2nd memset() argument 'varname' is a float, its representation is implementation defined. memset() is used to set each byte of a block of memory to a specific value and the actual representation of a floating-point value is implementation defined.

rule.name: The 2nd memset() argument 'varname' doesn't fit into an 'unsigned char'
rule.description:

CWE-686: Function Call With Incorrect Argument Type

rule.name: memset() called to fill 0 bytes

CWE-687: Function Call With Incorrectly Specified Argument Value

rule.name: 'class::operator=' should return 'class &'
rule.description:
The class::operator= does not conform to standard C/C++ behaviour. To conform to standard C/C++ behaviour, return a reference to self (such as: 'class &class::operator=(..) { .. return *this; }'. For safety reasons it might be better to not fix this message. If you think that safety is always more important than conformance then please ignore/suppress this message. For more details about this topic, see the book "Effective C++" by Scott Meyers.

References

CWE-398: 7PK - Code Quality

rule.description: Possible buffer overflow if strlen(source) is larger than or equal to sizeof(destination). The source buffer is larger than the destination buffer so there is the potential for overflowing the destination buffer.

rule.name: Prefer prefix ++/-- operators for non-primitive types
rule.description:
Prefix ++/-- operators should be preferred for non-primitive types. Pre-increment/decrement can be more efficient than post- increment/decrement. Post-increment/decrement usually involves keeping a copy of the previous value around and adds a little extra code.

rule.name: Passing NULL after the last typed argument to a variadic function leads to undefined behaviour
rule.description:
Passing NULL after the last typed argument to a variadic function leads to undefined behaviour. The C99 standard, in section 7.15.1.1, states that if the type used by va_arg() is not compatible with the type of the actual next argument (as promoted according to the default argument promotions), the behavior is undefined. The value of the NULL macro is an implementation-defined null pointer constant (7.17), which can be any integer constant expression with the value 0, or such an expression casted to (void*) (6.3.2.3). This includes values like 0, 0L, or even 0LL. In practice on common architectures, this will cause real crashes if sizeof(int) != sizeof(void*), and NULL is defined to 0 or any other null pointer constant that promotes to int. To reproduce you might be able to use this little code example on 64bit platforms. If the output includes "ERROR", the sentinel had only 4 out of 8 bytes initialized to zero and was not detected as the final argument to stop argument processing via va_arg(). Changing the 0 to (void*)0 or 0L will make the "ERROR" output go away. #include <stdarg.h> #include <stdio.h> void f(char *s, ...) { va_list ap; va_start(ap,s); for (;;) { char *p = va_arg(ap,char*); printf("%018p, %s\n", p, (long)p & 255 ? p : ""); if(!p) break; } va_end(ap); } void g() { char *s2 = "x"; char *s3 = "ERROR"; // changing 0 to 0L for the 7th argument (which is intended to act as sentinel) makes the error go away on x86_64 f("first", s2, s2, s2, s2, s2, 0, s3, (char*)0); } void h() { int i; volatile unsigned char a[1000]; for (i = 0; i<sizeof(a); i++) a[i] = -1; } int main() { h(); g(); return 0; }

rule.description: Internal limit: CheckLeakAutoVar::checkScope() Maximum recursive count of 1000 reached.

rule.name: Internal Error: Instantiation error
rule.description: Instantiation error: Divide by zero in template instantiation.

rule.name: Internal Error: Unmatched suppression
rule.description: Unmatched suppression: unusedFunction.

rule.name: misra-c2012-1.1: Violations of the standard C (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Violations of the standard C syntax and constraints

rule.name: misra-c2012-1.2: Language extensions (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) Language extensions should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-1.3: Unspecified behaviour (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) There shall be no occurrence of undefined or critical unspecified behaviour

rule.name: misra-c2012-2.1: Unreachable code (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A project shall not contain unreachable code

rule.name: misra-c2012-2.2: Dead code (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) There shall be no dead code

rule.name: misra-c2012-2.3: Unused type declarations (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A project should not contain unused ty pe declarations

rule.name: misra-c2012-2.4: Unused tag declarations (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A project should not contain unused tag declarations

rule.name: misra-c2012-2.5: Unused macro declarations (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A project should not contain unused macro declarations

rule.name: misra-c2012-2.6: Unused label declarations (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A function should not contain unused label declarations

rule.name: misra-c2012-2.7: Unused parameters in functions (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) There should be no unused parameters in functions

rule.name: misra-c2012-3.1: /* or // used within a comment (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The character sequences /* an d // shall not be used within a comment

rule.name: misra-c2012-3.2: Line-splicing in // comment (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Line-splicing shall not be used in // comments

rule.name: misra-c2012-4.1: Escape sequences not terminated (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated

rule.name: misra-c2012-4.2: Trigraphs (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) Trigraphs should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.1: Indistinct external identifiers (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) External identifiers shall be distinct

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.2: Indistinct identifiers in same scope (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Identifiers declared in the same scope and name space shall be distinct

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.3: Identifier hiding other identifier (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) An identifier declared in an inner scope shall not hide an identifier declared in an outer scope

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.4: Indistinct macro identifier (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Macro identifiers shall be distinct

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.5: Identifiers indistinct from macro names (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Identifiers shall be distinct from macro names

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.6: A typedef identifier not unique (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A typedef name shall be a unique identifier

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.7: Tag name identifier not unique (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A tag name shall be a unique identifier

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.8: Identifiers with external linkage not unique (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Identifiers that define objects or functions with external linkage shall be unique

rule.name: misra-c2012-5.9: Identifiers with internal linkage not unique (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Identifiers that define objects or functions with internal linkage should be unique

rule.name: misra-c2012-6.1: Bit-fields have not appropriate type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Bit-fields shall only be declared with an appropriate type

rule.name: misra-c2012-6.2: Single-bit is signed type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) Single-bit named bit fields shall not be of a signed type

rule.name: misra-c2012-7.1: Octal constants (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Octal constants shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-7.2: Unsigned constant integer required a 'U' or 'u' (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A u or U suffix shall be applied to all integer constants that are represented in an unsigned type

rule.name: misra-c2012-7.3: 'l' used in a literal suffix (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The lowercase character l shall not be used in a literal suffix

rule.name: misra-c2012-7.4: String literal assigned to wrong object (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A string literal shall not be assigned to an object unless the objects type is pointer to const-qualifi ed char

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.1: Types not explicitly specified (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Types shall be explicitly specified

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.2: Function prototype missing or incomplete (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Function types shall be in prototype form with named parameters

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.3: Different declaration of object function (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) All declarations of an object or function shall use the same names and type qualifiers

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.4: Non compatible declaration with external linkage (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A compatible declaration shall be visible when an object or function with external linkage is defined

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.5: An external element declared in several files (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) An external object or function shall be declared once in one and only one file

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.6: Symbol is redeclared or redefined (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) An identifier with external linkage shall have exactly one external definition

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.7: Functions or objects defined with external linkage and is referenced in only one translation unit (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) Functions and objects should not be defined with external linkage if they are referenced in only one translation unit

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.8: Storage class of symbol assumed static (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The static storage class specifier shall be used in all declarations of objects and functions that have internal linkage

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.9: Object define outside of block for single function usage (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) An object should be defined at block scope if its identifier only appears in a single function

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.10: Inline function defined without a storage-class specifier (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) An inline function shall be declared with the static storage class

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.11: Externale array without explicit size (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) When an array with external linkage is declared, its size should be explicitly specified

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.12: Element of enum whithout unique value (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Within an enumerator list, the value of an implicitly-specified enumeration constant shall be unique

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.13: Pointer parameter could be declared as pointing to const (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible

rule.name: misra-c2012-8.14: Restrict type used (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The restrict type qualifier shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-9.1: Symbol read before been set (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) The value of an object with automatic storage duration shall not be read before it has been set

rule.name: misra-c2012-9.2: Not initialized in braces (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The initializer for an aggregate or union shall be enclosed in braces

rule.name: misra-c2012-9.3: Init of array not complete (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Arrays shall not be partially initialized

rule.name: misra-c2012-9.4: Element initialized more than once (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) An element of an object shall not be initialized more than once

rule.name: misra-c2012-9.5: Size of the array not specified explicitly (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Where designated initializers are used to initialize an array object the size of the array shall be specified explicitly

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.1: Inapropriate essential type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Operands shall not be of an inappropriate essential type

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.2: Inapropriate ussage of character type in operation (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Expressions of essentially character type shall not be used inappropriately in addition and subtraction operations

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.3: Assignation of a narrower essential type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object with a narrower essential type or of a different essential type category

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.4: Operation with different type category (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Both operands of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed shall have the same essential type category

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.5: Cast to an inappropriate type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The value of an expression should not be cast to an inappropriate essential type

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.6: Assignation to object with wider essential type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The value of a composite expression shall not be assigned to an object with wider essential type

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.7: Implicit conversion in arithmetic conversion (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) If a composite expression is used as one operand of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed then the other operand shall not have wider essential type

rule.name: misra-c2012-10.8: Type conversion of composit expression (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The value of a composite expression shall not be cast to a different essential type category or a wider essential type

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.1: Convertion between pointer to function and other type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.2: Conversion between incomplete pointer type and other type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to an incomplete type and any other type

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.3: Cast between 2 pointers with different type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A cast shall not be performed between a pointer to object type and a pointer to a different object type

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.4: Conversion between pointer to object and pointer to integer (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object and an integer type

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.5: Conversion between pointer to void and pointer to object (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A conversion should not be performed from pointer to void into pointer to object

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.6: Conversion between pointer to void and arithmetic type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A cast shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.7: Conversion between pointer to object and non-integer arithmetic type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A cast shall not be performed between pointer to object and a non-integer arithmetic type

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.8: Pointer remove qualification to object (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A cast shall not remove any const or volatile qualification from the type pointed to by a pointer

rule.name: misra-c2012-11.9: Macro NULL used inappropriately (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The macro NULL shall be the only permitted form of integer null pointer constant

rule.name: misra-c2012-12.1: Precedence of expression non explicit (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The precedence of operators within expressions should be made explicit

rule.name: misra-c2012-12.2: The shift value is at least the precision of the essential type of the left hand side (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The right hand operand of a shift operator shall lie in the range zero to one less than the width in bits of the essential type of the left hand operand

rule.name: misra-c2012-12.3: Usage of coma operator (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The comma operator should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-12.4: Overflow in computing constant for operation (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) Evaluation of constant expressions should not lead to unsigned integer wrap-around

rule.name: misra-c2012-12.5: The parameter of the sizeof call is invalid (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) The sizeof operator shall not have an operand which is a function parameter declared as "array of type"

rule.name: misra-c2012-13.1: Initializer list with persistent side effect (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Initializer lists shall not contain persistent side effects

rule.name: misra-c2012-13.2: Different value of expression and persistent side effect (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The value of an expression and its persistent side effects shall be the same under all permitted evaluation orders

rule.name: misra-c2012-13.3: Unexpected side effect for (++) or (--) operation (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A full expression containing an increment (++) or decrement (--) operator should have no other potential side effects other than that caused by the increment or decrement operator

rule.name: misra-c2012-13.4: Utilisation of assignment operator result (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The result of an assignment operator should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-13.5: Side effects on right hand of logical operator (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The right hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain persistent side effects

rule.name: misra-c2012-13.6: Sizeof used on expression with side effect (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has potential side effects

rule.name: misra-c2012-14.1: Use of floating type in a loop (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A loop counter shall not have essentially floating type

rule.name: misra-c2012-14.2: For loop not correct (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A for loop shall be well-formed

rule.name: misra-c2012-14.3: Always evaluate to same value (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Controlling expressions shall not be invariant

rule.name: misra-c2012-14.4: Usage of non boolean control expression in if statement (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The controlling expression of an if statement and the controlling expression of an iteration-statement shall have essentially Boolean type

rule.name: misra-c2012-15.1: Usage of Goto (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The goto statement should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-15.2: Goto jump outside of autorized position (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the same function

rule.name: misra-c2012-15.3: Label declared outside of goto block or enclosing block (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in any block enclosing the goto statement

rule.name: misra-c2012-15.4: More than one goto or break to terminate operation (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) There should be no more than one break or goto statement used to terminate any iteration statement

rule.name: misra-c2012-15.5: More than one end point to exit function (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A function should have a single point of exit at the end

rule.name: misra-c2012-15.6: Sub-statement should be a compound statement (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The body of an iteration-statement or a selection-statement shall be acompound-statement

rule.name: misra-c2012-15.7: Else statment missing (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) All if ... else if constructs shall be terminated with an else statement

rule.name: misra-c2012-16.1: Switch statement not well formed (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) All switch statements shall be well-formed

rule.name: misra-c2012-16.2: Most closely-enclosing compound statement is not the body of a switch statement (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement

rule.name: misra-c2012-16.3: Break missing to terminate case (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) An unconditional break statement shall terminate every switch-clause

rule.name: misra-c2012-16.4: Default missing in the switch-case (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Every switch statement shall have a default label

rule.name: misra-c2012-16.5: Default not in first or salt label (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A default label shall appear as either the first or the last switch label of a switch statement

rule.name: misra-c2012-16.6: Switch statment does not have enough case (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses

rule.name: misra-c2012-16.7: Usage of boolean type for switch statment (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A switch-expression shall not have essentially Boolean type

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.1: Usage of stdarg.h is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The features of <stdarg.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.2: Function calling itself (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.3: Function declared implicitly (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) A function shall not be declared implicitly

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.4: Function should return a value (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) All exit paths from a function with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.5: Array has wrong size in function argument (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The function argument corresponding to a parameter declared to have an array type shall have an appropriate number of elements

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.6: Usage of static parameter of an array between [] (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) The declaration of an array parameter shall not contain the static keyword between the [ ]

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.7: Velue returned by function not used (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-17.8: Modification of function parameter (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) A function parameter should not be modified

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.1: Likely creation of out-of-bounds pointer (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A pointer resulting from arithmetic on a pointer operand shall address an element of the same array as that pointer operand

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.2: Substraction between different array with pointers (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Subtraction between pointers shall only be applied to pointers that address elements of the same array

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.3: Relational or subtract operator applied to pointers (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The relational operators >, >=, < and <= shall not be applied to objects of pointer type except where they point into the same object

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.4: Increment or subtract operator applied tp pointer (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The +, -, += and -= operators should not be applied to an expression of pointer type

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.5: More than 2 level of pointer (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) Declarations should contain no more than two levels of pointer nesting

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.6: Address of object with automatic storage affected to non persistant object (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be copied to another object that persists after the first object has ceased to exist

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.7: Usage of flexible array (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Flexible array members shall not be declared

rule.name: misra-c2012-18.8: Variable-length length arrya (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Variable-length array types shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-19.1: Assignation or copy to an overlapping object (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) An object shall not be assigned or copied to an overlapping object

rule.name: misra-c2012-19.2: Usage of Union Keyword (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The union keyword should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.1: #include misplaced (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) #include directives should only be preceded by preprocessor directives or comments

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.2: Wrong character used in header file name (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The ',' or \ characters and the /* or // character sequences shall not occur in a header file name

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.3: #include followed by wrong sequence (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.4: Macro name defined with a keyword (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.5: Usage of #undef (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) #undef should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.6: Apparent preprocessor directive in invocation of macro (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Tokens that look like a preprocessing directive shall not occur within a macro argument

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.7: Unparenthesized parameter in macro (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) Expressions resulting from the expansion of macro parameters shall be enclosed in parentheses

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.8: Conditional of #if does not evaluate to 0 or 1 (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The controlling expression of a #if or #elif preprocessing directive shall evaluate to 0 or 1

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.9: Undefined preprocessor variable (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) All identifiers used in the controlling expression of #if or #elif preprocessing directives shall be #define'd before evaluation

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.10: #or ## processor operator used (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.11: Stringize operator followed by macro parameter followed by pasting operator (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by a ## operator

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.12: Macro operator usedas an operand to # or ## and is subject to replacement (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.13: Not a valid preprocessing directive (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A line whose first token is # shall be a valid preprocessing directive

rule.name: misra-c2012-20.14: #else, #elif or #endif not in same file than #if, #ifdef or #ifndef (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.1: Illegal macro name with # usage (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) #define and #undef shall not be used on a reserved identifier or reserved macro name

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.2: Illegal macro name using reserved identifier (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) A reserved identifier or macro name shall not be declared

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.3: Usage of memory allocation and deallocation from stdlib.h is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The memory allocation and deallocation functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.4: Usage of setjmp.h is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The standard header file <setjmp.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.5: Usage of signal.h is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The standard header file <signal.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.6: Usage of input/output functions (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The Standard Library input/output functions shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.7: Usage of atol, atol and atoll is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The atof, atoi, atol and atoll functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.8: Usage of abort, exit, getenv and system is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The library functions abort, exit, getenv and system of <stdlib.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.9: Usage of bsearch and qsort is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The library functions bsearch and qsort of <stdlib.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.10: Usage of time and date function forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The Standard Library time and date functions shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.11: Usage of tgmath.h is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The standard header file <tgmath.h> shall not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.12: Usage of exception handling from fenv.h is forbidden (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Advisory) The exception handling features of <fenv.h> should not be used

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.13: Value passed to ctype.h function has an invalid type (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) Any value passed to a function in <ctype.h> shall be representable as an unsigned char or be the value EOF

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.15: Different pointer types in memcpy, memmove or memcmp function parameters (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The pointer arguments to the Standard Library functions memcpy, memmove and memcmp shall be pointers to qualified or unqualified versions of compatible types

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.16: Invalid pointer types in memcmp function parameters (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The pointer arguments to the Standard Library function memcmp shall point to either a pointer type, an essentially signed type, an essentially unsigned type, an essentially Boolean type or an essentially enum type

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.17: Read or write access beyond the bounds of an object passed as a parameter to function in string.h (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters

rule.name: misra-c2012-21.18: Size_t argument passed to string.h functions must be valid (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) The size_t argument passed to any function in <string.h> shall have an appropriate value

rule.name: misra-c2012-22.1: Custodial pointer has not been freed or returned (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) All resources obtained dynamically by means of Standard Library functions shall be explicitly released

rule.name: misra-c2012-22.2: Block of memory freed in bad conditions (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) A block of memory shall only be freed if it was allocated by means of a Standard Library function

rule.name: misra-c2012-22.3: Read and write function made in same time (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Required) The same file shall not be open for read and write access at the same time on different streams

rule.name: misra-c2012-22.4: Try to write on read only stream (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) There shall be no attempt to write to a stream which has been opened as read-only

rule.name: misra-c2012-22.5: Pointer to file dereferenced (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced

rule.name: misra-c2012-22.6: Value to pointer to file used after been closed (MISRA C 2012)
rule.description: (Mandatory) The value of a pointer to a FILE shall not be used after the associated stream has been closed
